Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: How does the brain represent abstract concepts?

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: The ability to reason about the relations between sets of concepts—relational reasoning—gives rise to abstract thought, and has fueled some of humanity’s greatest achievements in science and technology. Although prior research has identified where in the brain relational reasoning takes place, this project pushes the research field by addressing how the brain represents abstract relations. Specifically, the project aims to address three key questions: (1) Can the brain represent an abstract idea independently of the concrete entities that comprise the content of the idea? (2) Do people represent concepts in an abstract manner only when explicitly required to do so, or are abstract relations also retrieved spontaneously? (3) What neural markers reliably predict differences in reasoning capacity between individuals? That is, do individuals whose brains represent abstract relations more readily also tend to have stronger reasoning skills, and/or to perceive meaningful connections that others miss? This project will identify the computational basis for abstract thought and reasoning, thereby creating an opportunity to refine artificial intelligence systems by providing them with more efficient learning mechanisms. This work will inform future research examining how children, and adults as lifelong learners, form representations of abstract concepts. <br/><br/>This project integrates recent advances in multivariate fMRI, computational modeling, and behavioral methodology to discover the neurocognitive mechanisms underlying the representation of abstract relations. Research will systematically examine the neural bases of this representation, as well as the influence of task context and individual differences. First, behavioral priming and neural similarity measures, alongside metrics from a computational model of relational reasoning, will characterize the overlap in representation between pairs of concepts that are only abstractly related. Second, manipulation of task demands will determine whether the magnitude, location, and stability of neural representations vary with explicit cognitive instructions. Finally, development of a novel 'neural score' metric will determine neural markers of individual differences in relational reasoning.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have made important strides in this project, with further work ongoing. Thus far, we have published two empirical papers and have completed a third manuscript. These papers explore the phenomenon of relational luring, whereby individuals who have been exposed to a number of exemplars of a particular type of abstract relation (e.g., category: exemplar word pairs such as mammal-deer or vehicle-truck) are more likely to false-alarm to other exemplars of the same relation on a subsequent memory test in which previously encoded words are presented in pairs - that is, they are more likely to falsely remember word pairs that instantiate the same abstract relation as opposed to a relation they were not exposed to. This is true even though participants were never alerted to the presence of these categories of relations.

To further probe this recently discovered phenomenon of relational luring, which we have replicated with a novel paradigm, our team has modeled it computationally, showing that it can be explained in part by semantic processing and in part by automatic activation of abstract relations. Additionally, we have examined why individuals vary widely in the extent to which they exhibit relational luring. We have found that those who perform worse on a gold-standard test of abstract reasoning (Raven's Progressive Matrices) show less luring - that is, fewer errors; by contrast, those who perform better on tests of divergent thinking that involve semantic associations show *more* luring -- i.e., they are more likely to abstract away from specific exemplars to the more general relationship. Additionally, we have finalized fMRI data collection and have nearly finalized the analyses - resolving numerous technical challenges along the way - and have partially drafted one paper. We expect that these brain imaging analyses will yield at least two empirical papers. Findings to date are very promising; final analyses are forthcoming.      

This project has also provided numerous opportunities for training and professional development across the three sites, involving one graduate student who has moved onto a postdoctoral fellowship, a postdoctoral fellow, two lab managers who have moved onto graduate school, and five undergraduate research assistants. These trainees have had the wonderful opportunity to receive mentoring from multiple team members, including two or more faculty across sites. One of the former lab managers has moved from Berkeley to Dartmouth, and is continuing to work on the project as a graduate student. These trainees have learned psychological theory and developed or honed their skills in task design, project management, human subjects protocols, behavioral/brain imaging data collection, computational modeling, behavioral/brain imaging data analysis, scientific writing, conference presentation, and/or mentoring.
